For instance, if you see a car priced at $25,000, you're likely to perceive a car priced at $20,000 as a good deal, even if the actual market value of the car is closer to $15,000. <m> This bias can be overcome by meticulously examining all available information and relying solely on objective data. </m> However, in many situations, we struggle to completely detach from the initial anchor, leading to suboptimal decisions. While critical thinking and seeking diverse information can help,  the anchoring effect still persists to some degree. </hint>  Understanding this bias can help us make more informed choices by becoming aware of its potential influence on our thinking.
